properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are occurring near the Richardson Mountains. Winds easterly 80 km/h gusting to 100 and visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow will persist until late this morning. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Road closures are likely. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-03T22:11:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-03T10:48:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3609341538.2019
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Atmospheric conditions could result in a deterioration in air quality. High concentrations of pollutants should persist through Tuesday morning. Concentrations may increase once again Tuesday evening. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-12-03T16:59:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2019-12-03T03:58:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2389718579.2019
Area: Ashuapmushuan Wildlife Reserve area, Normandin - Péribonka area, Alma - Desbiens area, Saint-Félicien - Roberval area, Falardeau - Mont-Valin area, Sainte-Rose-du-Nord area, Ville de Saguenay area, Rivière-Éternité - Petit-Saguenay area, Tadoussac - Baie-Sainte-Catherine area

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow at times heavy with amounts of 15 to 25 centimetres is expected beginning this afternoon through Wednesday morning. The snow will be accompanied by strong northeasterly winds causing blowing snow at times, especially near the shoreline. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-04T01:48:06-00:00

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: AIR QUALITY ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR VANDERHOOF (December 2, 2019 - Smithers) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has continued an Air Quality Advisory for Vanderhoof because of high concentrations of fine particulate matter. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Staying indoors and in air conditioned spaces helps to reduce fine particulate exposure. Exposure is particularly a concern for infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-12-03T23:21:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2019-12-03T07:22:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2027679998.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected tonight and Wednesday. Locations: Eagle River and Cartwright to L'Anse-au-Clair. Time span: this evening until Wednesday evening. Possible snowfall: 10 to 20 cm except 5 to 10 cm along the coast from Mary's Harbour to L'Anse-au-Clair. Remarks: Snow will begin in the Straits area this evening then spread to the rest of southeastern and central Labrador during the night. Areas along the coast from L'Anse-au-Clair to Mary's Harbour are likely to see less accumulation as the snow is expected to be wet and mix with ice pellets. However, areas inland along the Trans Labrador Highway could see up to 20 cm by Wednesday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-04T07:20:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-03T15:21:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0655374073.2019
Area: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair, Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, Cartwright to Black Tickle, Eagle River

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A slow moving frontal system will remain over the BC interior today. Heavy snowfall associated with this storm will continue through tonight and taper off Wednesday morning. Snowfall accumulations of up to 40 cm are expected for this event. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of significant freezing rain is expected. Locations: southern, central and western Newfoundland. Time span: this afternoon until early Wednesday morning. Remarks: Freezing rain has begun over much of southern Newfoundland and will move northward during the afternoon. Total amounts of up to 10 mm are possible for parts of central and western Newfoundland. Precipitation is expected to change to rain for all areas by early Wednesday morning. ### Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-04T06:20:06-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain or freezing drizzle continuing over some areas this morning. Locations: Mainland Nova Scotia except the extreme southwestern areas. Time span: This morning. Remarks: Freezing rain and freezing drizzle will change to rain later this morning as temperatures rise above the freezing mark. This changeover is expected to occur by mid morning over southern areas and by late morning over northern areas. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. AIR QUALITY ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR COURTENAY (December 2, 2019 - Courtenay, BC) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Island Health is continuing an Air Quality Advisory for the Comox Valley because of high concentrations of fine particulate matter that are expected to persist until weather conditions change. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Staying indoors and in air conditioned spaces helps to reduce fine particulate exposure. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women and infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-12-04T00:02:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2019-12-03T08:03:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1292932389.2019
Area: Comox Valley

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Atmospheric conditions could result in a deterioration in air quality. High concentrations of pollutants should persist through Tuesday morning. Concentrations may increase once again Tuesday evening. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-12-03T16:59:23-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm continues. A slow moving frontal system is depositing heavy snow in the Shuswap region. Snowfall accumulations near 15 cm will fall by late this morning, particularly near Sicamous. Snow will ease late this morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-03T22:30:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-03T13:18:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3001750838.2019
Area: Shuswap
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Mixed precipitation this afternoon. Location: Prince Edward Island. Time span: today and tonight. Remarks: Rain and ice pellets with a risk of freezing rain are expected over western areas of Prince Edward Island this afternoon. Over central and eastern areas, rain will prevail. The precipitation will change to flurries after midnight. In addition, higher than normal water levels will combine with rough and pounding surf along northeastern facing shores of Prince Edward Island today, peaking near high tide this afternoon and extending into the early evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-04T07:08:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-03T15:09:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2240513396.2019
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. AIR QUALITY ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR GRAND FORKS (December 2, 2019 15:00 local Mountain time - Cranbrook) The Ministry of Environment & Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Interior Health Authority has issued an Air Quality Advisory for Grand Forks due to high concentrations of fine particulate matter that are expected to persist until weather conditions change. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. If you are experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, follow the advice of your health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce fine particulate exposure. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-12-04T06:27:32-00:00

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wreckhouse winds expected today. Maximum gusts: southeasterly 100 to 120 km/h. Time span: near noon to midnight tonight. ### Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
